title: 110_s2911
content: The Infant Immunization Improvement Act of 2008 may be cited as the Act. It includes a demonstration project for vaccination co-location services at WIC clinics. Section 317(k) of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow immunization grantees to use funds for providing recommended vaccines to children aged 0 to 35 months through WIC clinics, coordinating care or immunization services, and paying for an immunization coordinator's salary. Grantees with funding for an immunization information system must allow all participating clinics access to the system. The projects under this section aim to provide access to appropriate immunization services for children aged 0 to 35 months. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and State administrators of the program will consult with the Food and Nutrition Service of the Department of Agriculture. Activities will target areas with the greatest immunization needs in this age group. The term 'immunization information system' refers to a confidential system for tracking immunization records. An immunization information system is a confidential computerized system that collects vaccination data, generates reminders, and assesses coverage. An immunization coordinator coordinates immunization activities and referrals to providers. The Infant Immunization Improvement Act of 2008 authorizes $5,500,000 for each of the 3 fiscal years for immunization providers. SEC. 3. ANNUAL PUBLIC IMMUNIZATION AWARENESS CAMPAIGN. Section 317 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include an annual public immunization awareness campaign conducted by the Secretary through the CDC Director. The campaign aims to increase awareness of the benefits of immunizations, inform the public about new vaccines, and emphasize the benefits of recommended vaccines. Activities under this subsection shall target areas with the greatest immunization needs in the 0 to 35 month age group and shall be timed to coincide with national health observances. Additionally, $5,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated for each of the 3 fiscal years for immunization purposes. The Senate urges the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to enhance the integration of immunization information systems with electronic medical records and health information exchanges.
